title: 111_hr4416
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Ape Conservation Reauthorization Amendments Act of 2010" and includes amendments and reauthorization of the Great Ape Conservation Act. The Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to allow for multiyear grants for effective conservation projects and the implementation of awards for outstanding achievement in great ape conservation. The Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to acknowledge outstanding achievement in great ape conservation through awards, including cash awards not exceeding $7,500, noncash awards, posthumous awards, and public ceremonies. The Secretary may select up to three individuals annually for these awards. The Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 is amended to recognize significant contributions to great ape conservation by up to three individuals annually. Nominees must demonstrate selfless sacrifice and dedication to the conservation of great apes and their habitats. Guidelines for nominating award candidates will be published by the Secretary within 180 days of the enactment of this subsection. The guidelines for nominating award candidates under the Great Ape Conservation Act of 2000 will allow nominations of citizens and noncitizens of the United States. A panel of experts will convene within one year of the enactment of the Great Ape Conservation Reauthorization Amendments Act of 2010, and every 5 years thereafter, to prioritize needs for great ape conservation. The panel, including representatives from foreign range states with expertise in great ape conservation, will consider relevant conservation plans and strategies for great apes, including scientific research and findings. The Secretary may pay expenses for panel meetings, with a limit of $150,000 for administrative expenses. Authorization of appropriations is amended in section 6. Authorization of appropriations for the Fund to carry out the Act is as follows: $5,500,000 for fiscal year 2011, $6,000,000 for fiscal year 2012, $6,500,000 for fiscal year 2013, $7,000,000 for fiscal year 2014, and $7,500,000 for fiscal year 2015.
